From the 1980s to the present, [[Apple Inc.]] has been plaintiff or defendant in civil actions in the [[United States]] and other countries. Several of these actions have determined significant [[case law]] for the technology industry, while others simply captured the attention of the public and media. Apple's litigation generally involves [[intellectual property]] disputes, but it litigates in other areas as well. Between January 2008 and May 2010, Apple, Inc. filed more than 350 cases with the US Trademark office alone, most in opposition to or taking exception to others' use of the terms 'apple', 'pod', and 'safari': those cases include sellers of apples (the fruit), as well as many others' less unassuming use of the term 'apple'.<ref name="appleTTAB">U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pnam=Apple%20Inc.%20%20&page=15 US Trademark Trial and Appeal Board search for 'Apple Inc.'.]</ref>
==Antitrust claims== ===Apple iPod, iTunes antitrust litigation=== The case ''In re Apple iPod iTunes Antitrust Litigation'' was filed as a class-action in 2005 claiming Apple violated the U.S. [[Competition law|antitrust]] statutes in operating a music-downloading [[monopoly]] that it created by changing its software design to the proprietary [[FairPlay]] encoding in 2004, resulting in other vendors' music files being incompatible with and thus inoperable on the iPod.<ref>In re Apple iPod iTunes Antitrust Litig., No. C 05-00037 JW, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 107127, N.D. Cal. Dec. 22, 2008.</ref> The suit initially alleged that five days after [[RealNetworks]] released in 2004 its [[FairPlay#Harmony:_RealPlayer_Music_on_the_iPod|Harmony]] technology making its music playable on iPods, Apple changed its software such that the RealNetworks music would no longer play on iPods. The claims of Apple's changes to its encoding and its refusal to license FairPlay technology to other companies were dismissed by the court 2009, but the allegation of Apple's monopoly on the iPod's music download capabilities between 2004 and 2009 remain as of April 2011. On March 22, 2011, [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] news reported that after a related 3-year inquiry by the [[Competition Commission (United Kingdom)|Competition Commission]], Apple agreed in 2008 to lower its prices on iTunes tracks sold in the U.K.; and also reported that Steve Jobs had been directed by the court in March 2011 to make himself available to be [[Deposition (law)|deposed]] on Apple's FairPlay changes as they relate to the plaintiffs' monopolization claim.<ref name="MacLean">MacLean, Pamela, and Gullo, Karen, [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-22/apple-s-jobs-must-answer-questions-in-itunes-antitrust-dispute.html Appleâs Jobs Must Answer Questions in ITunes Antitrust Suit], Bloomberg, 2011-03-22.</ref>
===Apple and AT&T Mobility antitrust class action=== In the class action filed in 2008 against Apple, Inc. and [[AT&T Mobility|AT&T Mobility]]: ''In re Apple & AT&T Mobility Antitrust Litigation'',<ref name="AppleATT">In re Apple & AT & T M Antitrust Litigation, 596 F.Supp.2d 1288 (N.D.Cal. 2008).</ref> plaintiffs allege violations of the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]], breach of warranty under the [[MagnusonâMoss Warranty Act]], and other violations of consumer protection laws. In their complaint, plaintiffs allege that consumers were offered iPhones by Apple only if they signed a two-year service agreement with AT&T Mobility, but that unknown to consumers at the time of purchasing the iPhones, the two companies had agreed to technologically restrict voice and data service in the [[Aftermarket (merchandise)|aftermarket]] for continued voice and data services after the consumers' initial two-year service period expired, while at the same time continuing to share revenue stemming from provision of voice and data services to iPhone users. Plaintiffs allegations include that such an arrangement is a violation of the U.S. federal antitrust laws, of consumer protection laws, and of the [[Protected computer|Consumer Fraud and Abuse Act]]; that the arrangement constitutes monopolization of the aftermarket, that it constitutes a conspiracy to monopolize the aftermarket, and that as such and as an unfair and deceptive trade practice the alleged conduct deprives consumers of the benefit of their bargain in the purchase of iPhones. In October 2008 the court denied the defendants' motions to dismiss the case on the federal claims, granted their motions to dismiss the state unfair trade practice claims except in California, New York, and Washington, but gave the plaintiffs leave to amend those claims.<ref name="AppleATT" />
==Consumer class actions== ===Technical support class action=== From 1993 to 1996, Apple developed a marketing strategy that promised free unlimited live-telephone support on certain products for as long as the original purchaser owned it. However, by 1997, changes in Apple's [[AppleCare]] support policy led them to rescind the offer, resulting in a class action lawsuit which ultimately reinstated the phone support for the duration of original ownership of these otherwise obsolete products. Customers who were refused telephone service and charged per incident or incurred third party support charges were given a limited reimbursement.<ref>[http://www.info.apple.com/usen/legacy/legacyfaq.html Apple - Product Support (Language)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===iPod battery life class-action=== In 2004 and 2005, two state-level [[class action]]s were filed against Apple in New York and California, alleging the first, second, and third generation [[iPod]] music players sold prior to May 2004 did not have the battery life represented and/or that the battery's capacity to take and hold a charge substantially diminished over time.<ref name="appleipodsettlement">California case: ''In re iPod Cases'', Judicial Council Coordination Proceeding No. 4355, San Mateo County Superior Court; and New York action: ''Mosley v. Apple Computer, Inc.'', US District Court for the Southern District of New York, Case No. 7-04-cv-5773 (the "Mosley Action"). The information site Apple created for the California class action posted the [http://web.archive.org/web/20070705114128/www.appleipodsettlement.com/notice.html Notice of Pendency and Proposed Settlement of Class Action].</ref> Rather than litigate these claims, Apple entered into a settlement agreement in August 2005 after a fairness hearing in the California action, with the settlement designed to end the New York action as well by the settlement's terms. An appeal followed the California court's approval of the settlement but the appellate court upheld the settlement in December 2005. Eligible members of the class were entitled to extended warranties, store credit, cash compensation, or battery replacement, and some incentive payments, with all unfiled claims expiring after September 2005. Apple agreed to pay all costs of the litigation, including incentive payments to the class members and the plaintiffs' attorney fees, but admitted no fault.<ref name="appleipodsettlement" />
===iPad and iPhone privacy issue class-action===
In December 2010, [[Reuters]] reported that two separate groups of [[iPhone]] and [[iPad]] users have sued Apple, Inc. alleging that certain software applications were passing personal user information to third-party advertisers without consent.<ref name="Thomson Reuters">{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6BR1Y820101228|title=IPhone and iPad users sue Apple over privacy issues |author=Mukherjee and Ahmed|date=28 December 2010|work=[[Reuters]]|publisher=Thomson Reuters|accessdate=28 December 2010}}</ref> The cases are identified as: ''In re: Freeman et al v. Apple Inc et al'', No. 5:10-cv-05881-HRL and ''In re: Lalo v. Apple Inc et al'', No. 5:10-cv-05878-PSG, filed in the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of California]], San Jose division. The complainants seek a ban on the "passing of user information without consent and monetary compensation". The Reuters report said that in April, Apple had agreed to amend its developer agreement to stop this from happening "except for information directly necessary for the functionality of the apps" however the lawsuit alleges that Apple has taken no steps to do this or enforce it "in any meaningful way due to criticism from advertising networks."<ref name="Thomson Reuters" />
The [[Associated Press]] reported a pending congressional inquiry into the matter, with [[United States Congress]] members stating that commercial storage and usage of location information without a consumer's express consent is illegal under current law, but Apple defended its use of customer tracking in a letter released May 9, 2011 by the House of Representatives.<ref name="CongressInquiry">Jordan Robertson, AP Technology Writer, [http://www.seattlepi.com/news/article/Apple-slammed-over-iPhone-iPad-location-tracking-1347304.php Apple Slammed Over iPhone, iPad Location Tracking], Seattle PI, 2011-04-24.</ref><ref name="Logging">Associated Press, [http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=135605569 Apple Defends IPhone 'Hot Spot'-Logging], NPR, 2011-05-10.</ref> [[NPR]]'s senior director of technology published an article examining the data collected by his own iPhone, showing examples of the data collected and maps correlating the data.<ref name="Brand-NPR">Brand, Zach, [http://www.npr.org/blogs/alltechconsidered/2011/04/24/135639390/sifting-through-an-iphones-data-row-by-row Sifting Through An iPhone's Geo Data, Row By Row], National Public Radio, All Tech Considered, 2011-04-23.</ref> Separately, digital forensics researchers reported they regularly use the data collected in working with law enforcement officials investigating crimes and have been doing so since at least mid-2010.<ref name="Wolverton">Wolverton, Troy, [http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_17903104 Investigators use iPhones to track owners' movements], San Jose Mercury News, 2011-04-21.</ref> In contrast with earlier statements, Apple revealed in a hearing with the US Senate Judiciary Committee that a "software bug" caused iPhones to continue to send anonymous location data to the company's servers, even when location services on the device were turned off.<ref name="Tessler">Tessler, Joelle, Associated Press, [http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_18138774 Sen. Al Franken calls for Apple, Google app privacy policies], San Jose Mercury News, 2011-05-25.</ref>
===iTunes price-switching class action=== In June 2009, complainants filed the class action suit ''Owens v. Apple, Inc.'' against Apple, Inc. seeking to certify a nationwide class of individuals who purchased iTunes gift cards. The complaint alleges that Apple wrongfully marketed, distributed and sold iTunes gift cards and songs through its online iTunes store, while representing to consumers that they could use the gift cards to purchase songs for $.99 a song, and then after such gift cards were purchased, raised the price on certain songs to $1.29 on April 7, 2009. Complainants allege Apple's conduct constitutes breach of contract, violates the state consumer fraud statute, and violates consumer protection statutes of other states. Plaintiffs seek a remedy of $.30 refund for each song that Plaintiffs and other class members purchased using a $.99 iTunes card for which they were charged $1.29, plus their attorneys' fees and costs.<ref name="owensCA">Owens v. Apple, Inc., 09-cv-0479-MJR, USDC S.Dist. Illinois, 2009.</ref> Apple sought to dismiss the suit but lost its motion in December 2009.<ref name="owensCA" />
==Unfair trade practice== ===Resellers v. Apple=== In 2004, independent Apple resellers filed a lawsuit against the company alleging misleading advertising practices and unfair business practices were harming sales while boosting company owned Apple outlets.<ref>{{cite news|last=Oates|first=John|url=http://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/06/16/apple_gets_sued/|title=Apple resellers are revolting|publisher=[[The Register]]|date=2004-06-16|accessdate=2007-05-02}}</ref> The lawsuit claimed that Apple had favored Apple stores by providing significant discounts that were unavailable to independent dealers. The complaint further accused the corporation of breach of contract, false advertising, fraud, trade libel, defamation, and intentional interference with prospective economic advantage. As of 2006, Apple had reached settlements with all of the plaintiffs, including the bankruptcy trustee for one reseller that failed. The former principal of that company has appealed the bankruptcy court's approval of the settlement.<ref>[http://media.corporate-ir.net/media_files/irol/10/107357/10K_2006.pdf Apple 10K p.41]</ref>
==Defamation== ===Libel dispute with Carl Sagan=== {{See also|Carl Sagan#Personal life and beliefs|l1=Personal life and beliefs of Carl Sagan}} In 1994, engineers at [[Apple Computer]] code-named the mid-level [[Power Macintosh 7100]] "[[Carl Sagan]]" after the popular astronomer in the hope that Apple would make "billions and billions" with the sale of the PowerMac 7100.<ref name="Poundstone">{{cite book | last=Poundstone | first=William | title=Carl Sagan: A Life in the Cosmos | pages=363â364, 374â375 | location=New York | publisher=Henry Holt & Company | year=1999 | isbn=0-805-05766-8}}</ref> The name was only used internally, but Sagan was concerned that it would become a product endorsement and sent Apple a cease and desist letter.<ref>Poundstone, p. 363.</ref> Apple complied, but engineers retaliated by changing the internal codename to "BHA" for "Butt-Head Astronomer".<ref name="Poundstone, p. 364">Poundstone, p. 364</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.macobserver.com/columns/thisweek/2004/20041120.shtml | title=This Week in Apple History: November 14â20 | publisher=The Mac Observer}}</ref> Sagan then sued Apple for libel, a form of [[defamation]], in federal court. The court granted Apple's motion to dismiss Sagan's claims and opined in [[Obiter dictum|dicta]] that a reader aware of the context would understand Apple was "clearly attempting to retaliate in a humorous and satirical way", and that "It strains reason to conclude that Defendant was attempting to criticize Plaintiff's reputation or competency as an astronomer. One does not seriously attack the expertise of a scientist using the undefined phrase 'butt-head'."<ref name="Poundstone, p. 364"/><ref>Sagan v. Apple Computer, Inc., 874 F.Supp. 1072 (USDC C.D. Cal. 1994), CV 94-2180 LGB (BRx); 1994 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20154.</ref> Sagan then sued for Apple's original use of his name and likeness, but again lost.<ref name="Poundstone, p. 374">Poundstone, p. 374</ref> Sagan appealed the ruling.<ref name="Poundstone, p. 374"/> In November 1995, an out of court settlement was reached and Apple's office of trademarks and patents released a conciliatory statement that "Apple has always had great respect for Dr. Sagan. It was never Apple's intention to cause Dr. Sagan or his family any embarrassment or concern."<ref>Poundstone, pp. 374-375.</ref>
==Intellectual property== ===Trademark=== ====Trademark disputes with Apple Corps==== {{main|Apple Corps v. Apple Computer}} In 1978, [[Apple Corps]] ([[The Beatles]]-founded record label and holding company) filed suit against Apple Computer for trademark infringement. The suit settled in 1981 with an undisclosed amount being paid to Apple Corps, later revealed to be US$80,000.<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/sep2004/tc20040930_9317_tc056.htm John, Paul, George, Ringo...and Steve?], businessweek.com. September 30, 2004.</ref> As a condition of the settlement, Apple Computer agreed to stay out of the music business. In 1991, after the introduction of the [[Apple IIgs]], a computer with an [[Ensoniq]] music synthesizer chip, which Apple Corps alleged to be in violation, another settlement of around US$26.5 million was reached, and Apple Computer agreed that it would not package, sell or distribute physical music materials.<ref>Borland and Fried, [http://news.cnet.com/Apple-vs.-Apple-Perfect-harmony/2100-1027_3-5378401.html Apple vs. Apple: Perfect harmony?], CNet News, 2004-09-23.</ref>
In September 2003, Apple Computer was sued by Apple Corps again, this time for introducing [[iTunes]] and the [[iPod]] which Apple Corps believed was a violation of the previous agreement by Apple not to distribute music. The trial opened on March 29, 2006 in the UK.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4854408.stm Apple giants do battle in court]</ref> Judgement was issued in favor of Apple Computer on May 8, 2006.<ref>Breaking news: "Apple Computer wins court battle with Beatles", [[Reuters]], 8 May 2006 ([http://today.reuters.com/business/newsarticle.aspx?type=ousiv&storyID=2006-05-08T095845Z_01_L08592117_RTRIDST_0_BUSINESSPRO-MEDIA-APPLE-JUDGMENT-DC.XML link])</ref><ref>Brandle, L. "Apple Computer Triumphs In Beatles Case", ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'', 8 May 2006 ([http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002464164 link])</ref> "I find no breach of the trademark agreement has been demonstrated," the presiding Justice Mann said.<ref>[http://www.hmcourts-service.gov.uk/judgmentsfiles/j4226/apple_v_apple_hc03c02428_0506.htm High Court Judgement] from the website of [[Her Majesty's Courts Service]]</ref><ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,200-2170977,00.html Transcript of full judgement] from ''[[The Times]]'', 8 May 2006</ref>
On February 5, 2007, Apple Inc. and Apple Corps announced a settlement of their trademark dispute under which Apple Inc. will own all of the trademarks related to âAppleâ and will license certain of those trademarks back to Apple Corps for their continued use. The settlement ends the ongoing trademark lawsuit between the companies, with each party bearing its own legal costs, and Apple Inc. will continue using its name and logos on iTunes. The settlement includes terms that are confidential.<ref>[http://www.apple.com/pr/library/2007/02/05apple.html Apple Inc. and The Beatlesâ Apple Corps Ltd. Enter into New Agreement<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
====Trademark dispute over ''appleimac.com''==== In July 1998, [[Abdul Traya]] registered the domain name ''appleimac.com'', two months before Apple announced the [[iMac]], in an attempt to draw attention to the web-hosting business he was running out of his parents' basement. A note on his site stated that his plan was to "''generate traffic to our servers and try to put the domain to sale. [sic]''"<ref>[http://news.com.com/2100-1023-221921.html Teen in dispute with Apple over domain - CNET News.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> After a legal dispute that lasted until April 1999, Traya and Apple settled out of court with Apple paying legal fees and giving Traya a "''token payment''" in exchange for the domain name.<ref>[http://www.macobserver.com/news/99/april/990427/applevsteen.html The Mac Observer-Battle For Domain Name Between Apple And Teen Resolved<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
====Trademark dispute over ''itunes.co.uk''==== The iTunes case was important because it turned around prior decisions by awarding a domain name to a subsequent registrant (Apple), rather than to the prior registrant (Cohen). (The full text of the following decision, including the full history of the use of the domain, is available at [http://www.nominet.org.uk/digitalAssets/766_itunes.pdf nominet.org.uk.)] In November 2000, [[Benjamin Cohen (internet)|Benjamin Cohen]] of [[CyberBritain]] registered the domain name ''itunes.co.uk''. The domain was initially pointed to skipmusic.com, then to cyberbritain.com and then inoperative for some time. Apple applied for a UK trademark for ''iTunes'' on October 23, 2000, and this was granted on March 23, 2001. Apple launched its popular iTunes music store service in the UK in 2004. Once they had done this, Cohen reactivated the domain name, which was then for a while redirected to iTunes' then-biggest rival, [[Napster]]. The domain name then forwarded to CyberBritain's cash back/rewards website. In 2005, Apple took the matter to the Dispute Resolution Service operated by [[.uk]] [[domain name registry]] [[Nominet UK]] (the DRS), stating that they had rights in the name "iTunes" and that the use of the domain name by Cohen's company was abusive (these being the two tests under the DRS rules). The dispute was not resolved at the free mediation stage and Apple paid for an independent expert to decide the case, who decided in Apple's favor in the dispute. Cohen immediately launched a media offensive stating that the DRS was biased towards large businesses and made frequent threats of lawsuits against Nominet.<ref>McCarthy, Kieren, [http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/05/27/itunes_no_nominet/ Cohen disputes UK registry's legitimacy], The Register, Financial News, 27 May 2005.</ref>
Cohen then stated that the DRS was unfair for a number of reasons and stated that he would take Nominet to the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]] via [[judicial review]]. Nominet said that he should appeal the case via the appeal process in the DRS. Cohen refused to do this, and after several months did issue proceedings.<ref>Richardson, Tim, [http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/06/17/itunes_nominet/ Nominet faces judicial review over itunes.co.uk ownership], The Register, Music and Media, 17 June 2005.</ref> The judge at first instance rejected his case noting that Cohen's company, Cyberbritain Group Ltd, should have used the appeal process which forms part of Nominet's domain resolution service, and Cohen's company asked for a rehearing. As that case progressed, the interim domain name was transferred to Apple in accordance with the expert's decision and it now points to the music site. In November 2005, Cohen dropped all legal action against Apple.<ref>Richardson, Tim, [http://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/11/25/cohen_itunes/ Cohen ends legal bid for itunes.co.uk], Financial News, The Register, 25 November 2005.</ref>
====iPhone trademark==== On January 10, 2007, [[Cisco Systems]] filed a lawsuit against Apple, standing that Apple's [[iPhone]] infringed on their [[Linksys iPhone|iPhone]] trademark. The two companies were in negotiation to allow Apple the rights to use the name, although the meetings came to standstill when Cisco pushed for the two products to be interoperable. Cisco has alleged that Apple subsequently created a front company to try to acquire the rights another way. Following the public unveiling of the iPhone at the 2007 [[Macworld Expo]], Cisco filed the lawsuit. Apple claimed that there will be no confusion between the two products, and that their iPhone is the first cell phone with such a name, Cisco's "iPhone" being a [[VoIP]] phone.<ref>[http://news.com.com/Cisco+sues+Apple+over+use+of+iPhone+trademark/2100-1047_3-6149285.html Cisco sues Apple over use of iPhone trademark] | [[CNET News]]</ref> On February 21, 2007, Cisco and Apple announced an agreement under which both companies would be allowed to use the iPhone name worldwide.<ref>[http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20070222/bs_nm/apple_cisco_dc_5 Cisco and Apple can both use iPhone name] [[Yahoo!]] News, February 22, 2007.</ref>
====Trademark dispute with New York City over an apple-shaped mark==== In January 2008, Apple filed an opposition with the US [[Trademark Trial and Appeal Board]] (TTAB) against [[New York City]]'s (NYC) trademark application for the "[[Big Apple]]" logo for NYC's [[GreeNYC]] initiative.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2008/apr/04/business/fi-apple4 Apple challenges NYC bid for new 'Big Apple' logo], Los Angeles Times, April 04, 2008.</ref> NYC originally filed for its trademark: "a stylized apple design" for "Education services, namely, providing public service announcements on policies and practices of the City of New York in the field of environmentally sustainable growth" on May 14, 2007, and then amended its application on Jun 27, 2007.<ref name="nyTM">[http://tmportal.uspto.gov/external/portal/tow?SRCH=Y&isSubmitted=true&details=&SELECT=US+Serial+No&TEXT=77179942 Trademark application and history, #77179942.]</ref> The TTAB's Notice of Publication was published September 18, 2007, and then Apple filed an opposition with the TTAB the following January, claiming a likelihood of confusion.<ref>Apple, Inc. opposition to NYC & Company, Inc., Opp. No. [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/v?pno=91181984&pty=OPP 91181984].</ref> On June 26, 2008, NYC filed a motion to amend its application to delete the leaf element from its design, leaving the stem, and the TTAB dismissed the Apple's opposition and counterclaims in accordance with the parties' stipulation on July 22, 2008.<ref>U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, [http://ttabvue.uspto.gov/ttabvue/ttabvue-91181984-OPP-9.pdf TTAB dismissal of Apple opposition and counterclaim], July 22, 2008.</ref> As of February 23, 2010, NYC's trademark application is pending.<ref>U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, [http://tarr.uspto.gov/servlet/tarr?regser=serial&entry=77179942 NYC Trademark Status], Trademark Trial and Appeal Board, February 23, 2010; and [http://tmportal.uspto.gov/external/portal/tow?SRCH=Y&isSubmitted=true&details=&SELECT=US+Serial+No&TEXT=77179942 USPTO TDR Portlet for Serial No. 77179942.]</ref>
====Trademark dispute with the Victoria School of Business and Technology==== In September 2008, Apple sent a cease and desist letter<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qcollege.ca/about-q-college/blog/apples-and-oranges-vsbt-vs-apple-inc-logo-dispute|title= Apples and Oranges: VSBT vs. Apple Inc. Logo Dispute|publisher=Q College |date= |accessdate=2011-01-02}}</ref> to the Victoria School of Business and Technology in [[Saanich, British Columbia]], claiming the school's logo infringed upon Appleâs rights. Apple also claimed that the school's logo falsely suggested Apple had authorized the school's activities.<ref name="vicBusTech">[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/story/2008/10/06/bc-school-apple-logo.html No Apple for Vancouver Island School, Says Computer Corporation], CBC News, 6 Oct 2008.</ref> The logo in question featured the outline of an apple and a leaf, however, its design incorporated a mountain and had three bumps on top instead of the two used by Apple, additionally, there was no bite out of the school's apple.<ref name="ctvFruit">CTV [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/technology/article714826.ece Will Apple's suit against B.C. school bear fruit?], Globe & Mail, 6 Oct 2008.</ref> In April 2011, the Victoria School of Business and Technology reported it had settled its 3-year dispute with Apple, was launching a new logo under a new name, Q College, and was expanding its operations.<ref name="vicTimesColonist">[http://www2.canada.com/victoriatimescolonist/news/business/story.html?id=b44805cb-d044-461c-883f-8f615d3079a5 Business school drops use of Apple's forbidden fruit], Times Colonist, 1 Apr 2011.</ref>
====Trademark dispute with Woolworths Limited over Apple logo==== In October 2009, Apple disputed a trademark application by [[Woolworths Limited]] in [[Australia]] over its new [[Woolworths (supermarket)|supermarket]] logo,<ref>{{cite news | title = Apple bites over Woolworths logo | first = Julian | last = Lee | url = http://www.theage.com.au/business/apple-bites-over-woolworths-logo-20091005-ghzr.html | newspaper = [[The Age]] | location = [[Melbourne]] | date = 5 October 2009 }}</ref> a stylised green "W", similar in shape to an apple.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=The Age, Melbourne|date=2008-08-21|accessdate=2008-08-21| title=Woolies shelves Safeway brand|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/woolies-shelves-safeway-brand-20080820-3ywj.html | first=Ari | last=Sharp}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=Woolworths Limited|title=Woolworths launches new look after 21 years|date=2008-08-22| accessdate=2008-08-23|url=http://www.woolworths.com.au/resources/woolworths+launches+new+look+after+21+years.pdf|format=PDF}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Apple reportedly took objection to the breadth of Woolworths' application, which would allow it to brand products, including consumer electronics, with the logo.
====Apple v. DOPi==== In March 2010, an Australian Trademarks tribunal denied Apple's attempt to prevent a small company from trademarking the name DOPi for use on its laptop bags and cases for Apple products. Apple argued that the DOPi name - which is iPod spelled backwards - is too similar to its own product's name, the iPod.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/digital-life/mp3s/apples-future-wont-be-brought-to-you-by-the-letter-i-20100312-q27r.html |date=12 March 2010 |title=Apple's future won't be brought to you by the letter 'i' |publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald|SMH]] | first1=Julian | last1=Lee | first2=Asher | last2=Moses}}</ref> The order effectively meant that Apple can no longer have exclusive claim to the letter 'i'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://techpp.com/2010/03/12/apple-cannot-monopolize-the-letter-i-igood/ |date=12 March 2010 |title=Apple Cannot Monopolize the Letter âiâ|publisher=techpp}}</ref>
====Apple v. Amazon.com: "App Store" dispute==== In 2011 Apple filed suit against [[Amazon.com]], alleging trademark infringement and unfair competition over Amazon's use of the "App Store" phrase relating to Amazon's "[[Amazon Appstore]] Developer Portal" and Amazon's alleged other similar uses of the phrase.<ref name="AppStore">Apple Inc v. Amazon.com Inc., 11-1327, USDC ND Ca. (2011).</ref> Reuters reported that in the case Microsoft is opposing Apple's attempted registration of the phrase as a trademark, and that part of the matter is currently before the [[Trademark Trial and Appeal Board]].<ref name="Levine">Levine, Dan, [http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wpr/news.newsmain/article/0/5/1778634/Business/Apple.sues.Amazon.com.over.APP.STORE.trademark Apple sues Amazon.com over APP STORE trademark], Reuters, 2011-03-22.</ref> In June 2011, U.S. District Judge Phyllis Hamilton, who is presiding over Apple's case against Amazon, said she'll "probably" deny Apple's motion that seeks to bar the Web retailer from using the "App Store" name.<ref name="LowensohnDeny">Lowensohn, Josh, [http://news.cnet.com/8301-27076_3-20073524-248/judge-likely-to-deny-apples-appstore-complaint/ Judge likely to deny Apple's 'Appstore' complaint], CNET News, 2011-6-22.</ref><ref name="RosenblattGullo">Rosenblatt, Joel, and Gullo, Karen, [http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-06-22/apple-bid-to-bar-amazon-appstore-will-likely-be-denied.html Apple Bid to Bar Amazon 'Appstore' Will 'Likely' Be Denied], Bloomberg Businessweek, 2011-6-22.</ref><ref name="ToughRoad">{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/22/us-apple-amazon-idUSTRE75L79Y20110622 | work=Reuters | title=Apple may have tough road in Amazon lawsuit | date=2011-06-22}}</ref>
===Trade secret=== ====Apple v. Does==== {{main|Apple v. Does}} In November 2004, three popular [[weblog]] sites that feature [[Mac rumors community|Apple rumors]] publicly revealed information about two unreleased Apple products, the [[Mac mini]] and an as yet unreleased product code-named ''Asteroid'', also known as ''Project Q97''. The journalists appealed, and in May 2006, the California Court of Appeal reversed the trial court's decision, ruling that activities in question are covered by the shield law. The court adamantly chastized Apple's litigiousness by remarking: <blockquote style="margin: 6px 60px;"> ... the discovery process is intended as a device to facilitate adjudication, not as an end in itself. To accept Appleâs position on the present point would empower betrayed employers to clothe themselves with the subpoena power merely by suing fictitious defendants, and then to use that power solely to identify treacherous employees for purposes of discipline, all without any intent of pursuing the underlying case to judgment. An employer pursuing such an objective might prefer not to join any defendants lest it expose itself to negative consequences up to and including a countersuit for malicious prosecution or abuse of process. Our sympathy for employers in such a position cannot blind us to the gross impropriety of using the courts and their powers of compulsory process as a tool and adjunct of an employerâs personnel department.<ref>O'Grady v. Superior Court, 44 Cal.Rptr.3d 72, 139 Cal.App.4th 1423, modified by O'Grady v. Superior Court, 140 Cal.App.4th 675b.</ref></blockquote>

===Copyright=== ====Apple v. Franklin==== {{main|Apple Computer, Inc. v. Franklin Computer Corp.}} In 1982, Apple filed a lawsuit against [[Franklin Computer Corp.]], alleging that Franklin's ACE 100 personal computer used illegal copies of the [[Apple II]]'s [[operating system]] and [[Read-only memory|ROM]]. Decided in Franklin's favor but reversed by the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, Apple v. Franklin established the fundamental basis of copyright of computer software, even if it was provided only as object code or in firmware.<ref>Apple Computer, Inc. v. Franklin Computer Corp., 714 F.2d 1240 (3d Cir. 1983).</ref>
====Object code cases and conflicts of law==== Apple's litigation over [[overhead code|object code]] (see also [[object file]]) was seminal in the development of contemporary copyright law because the company's object code cases brought different results in different courts. In the 1980s, Apple litigated two now-famous copyright cases with central issues that included the question of whether object code (as contrasted with [[source code]]) of a computer program is subject to copyright laws. A third case not involving Apple but involving the Apple decisions followed in New Zealand. The specific cases involved were ''Computer Edge Pty. Ltd. v Apple Computer Inc.'' (1986, Australia),<ref name="computerEdge">Computer Edge Pty. Ltd. v Apple Computer Inc. (1986) 65 ALR 33; [1986] F.S.R. 537, (High Court of Australia).</ref> ''Apple Computer Inc. v Mackintosh Computers Ltd.'' (1987, Canada),<ref name="ApplevMac">Apple Computer Inc. v Mackintosh Computers Ltd. (1987) 44 DLR (4th) 74 (Canadian Federal Court of Appeal) (later affirmed, [http://csc.lexum.umontreal.ca/en/1990/1990scr2-209/1990scr2-209.html Supreme Court of Canada]).</ref> and ''IBM v. Computer Imports Ltd.'' (1989, New Zealand).<ref name="nzIBM">International Business Machines Corporation v. Computer Imports Limited [1989] 2 NZLR 395, 409.</ref>
In the Computer Edge case, the Australian court decided against the then-prevailing opinions in other courts (the UK, Canada, South Africa, and the US) and ruled object code was not copyrightable;<ref name="CE2">In Computer Edge the court looked to 1986 161 CLR 171 (test in Exxon for literary work is "not intended to establish a comprehensive or exhaustive definition of literary work for copyright purposes" per Mason and Wilson JJ (Aus.)).</ref> while the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] in Apple v. Mackintosh reversed its earlier decisions and ruled that because object code was a translation of source code and embodied in a silicon chip, it was therefore a translation of an original literary work expressed in a material form and unauthorized reproduction of the object code was therefore an infringement of copyright. The Canadian court opined that programs within [[Read-only memory|ROM]] silicon chips are protected under the [[Copyright Act of Canada]], and the conversion from the source code into object code is a form of ''translation''. It further held that such translation does not include the expression of an idea in another form, but rather only applies to the expression of an idea in another language, and that a translation has a one-to-one correspondence between works that are expressed in two different languages.
In these [[conflict of laws]] cases, Apple met with conflicting international judicial opinions: an Australian court decision conflicted with a Canadian court decision on the copyrightability of object code. The New Zealand High Court then considered these prior decisions and sided with the Canadian decision in ruling that although object code is not an original literary work in its own right, it is a reproduction of source code in material form and therefore an infringement of copyright takes place if it is copied without the authorization of the copyright owner. These legal conflicts affected not only Apple but all other software companies, and remained unresolved until the creation of an international legal regime embodied in further changes to national copyright laws, which ultimately made object code subject to copyright law.<ref name="copyrtChgs">The 1994 Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPs), the 1991 European Economic Council Directive on the Legal Protection of Computer Programs ("EC Directive"), the [[Copyright Act of Canada]], the New Zealand Copyright Act of 1994, and other national copyright law revisions.</ref>
These revisions to copyright law in favor of including object code are still controversial,<ref name="Corbett">Corbett, Susan, [http://www.victoria.ac.nz/sacl/research/seminars/documents2007/sc_230307.pdf What if Object Code Had Been Excluded from Protection as a Literary Work in Copyright Law?], a paper for presentation at the 4th Annual Intellectual Property Conference: Rewriting History: Counterfactuals and Alternative Stories in Intellectual Property and Cyberspace Law, Michigan State Univ. College of Law, March 2007.</ref> and form the technical underpinnings for the legal notion of computer trespass and the following development of anti-hacking law-making such as the [[Patriot Act]] and such as are defined by the [[Convention on Cybercrime]].
====Apple v. Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard==== {{main|Apple Computer, Inc. v. Microsoft Corp.}} In 1988, after the introduction of [[Microsoft Windows 2.0|Windows 2.0]], Apple filed a lawsuit against [[Microsoft]] and [[Hewlett-Packard]] alleging that [[Microsoft Windows]] and HP's [[NewWave (HP software)|NewWave]] violated Apple's copyrights in the Macintosh user interface. After several years in court, Apple's claims against Microsoft were dismissed, primarily due to a license [[John Sculley]] had negotiated with [[Bill Gates]] for Windows 1.0. The decision was upheld on appeal in 1994, but legal disputes on this topic were still ongoing until 1997, when the two companies came to a wide-ranging agreement that included Microsoft buying non-voting Apple stocks.<ref name=applemscnet>Kawamoto, Dawn; Heskett, Ben; Ricciuti, Mike. ====Typhoon Touch Technologies touch screen patents==== In June 2008, Apple was named among others as a defendant in a suit alleging [[patent infringement]] in portable [[touch screen]] technology. The suit was important for illustrating the vagaries of litigating patent licensing and royalty collection issues in the commercial exploitation of intellectual property rights. The plaintiff, Typhoon Touch Technologies, acquired two pre-existing patents, (filed in 1993 and 1994 and issued in 1995 and 1997), in mid-2007 for $350,000 plus a percentage of collected licensing fees.<ref name="redflags">Harris, Larry, [http://seekingalpha.com/article/84206-red-flags-at-typhoon-touch-technologies Red Flags at Typhoon Touch Technologies], Seeking Alpha, 2008-7-9.</ref> The patents had languished for some time and were not being policed, however Typhoon sought to begin enforcement by bringing suit against infringers. Shortly after Typhoon acquired the patents, it began to sue exploiters of the technology who had not paid licensing fees. Typhoon was successful in its patent infringement suits against some small companies, and then expanded its litigation to go after larger companies. Typhoon alleged that Apple and others used its patented technology inventions without permission. The suit was filed in the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas]], Tyler Division, Case No. 6:07-cv-546,<ref name="typhoonSuit">Typhoon Touch Techs. v. Dell, Inc., No. 6-07-cv-546 (E.D. Tex. filed Oct. 23, 2008).</ref> and identified the technology as U.S. Patent No. 5,379,057: "Portable Computer with Touch Screen and Computer System Employing Same," and U.S. Patent No. 5,675,362: "Portable Computer with Touch Screen and Computing System Employing Same". Typhoon originally filed the suit in December 2007 against [[Dell]] after settling with some smaller companies, but in mid-2008 amended its complaint to add Apple,<ref>Plaintiffâs Third Amended Complaint for Patent Infringement at 5â6, Typhoon Touch Techs., Inc. v. Dell, Inc., No. 6:07-cv-00546-LED (E.D. Tex. Mar. 6, 2009) (asserting,inter alia, that the iPhone infringes U.S. Patent Nos. 5,379,057 and 5,675,362); and see Seaman, Christopher B., [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/Delivery.cfm/SSRN_ID1793342_code1411637.pdf?abstractid=1575805&mirid=1 Reconsidering the Georgia-Pacific Standard for Reasonable Royalty Patent Damages], BYU Law Review, No. 5, p. 1661, 2010; Chicago-Kent Intellectual Property, Science & Technology Research Paper No. 10-030, 2011-2-1.</ref> [[Fujitsu]], [[Toshiba]], [[Lenovo]], [[Panasonic Corporation|Panasonic]], [[HTC Corporation|HTC]], [[Palm, Inc.|Palm]], [[Samsung]], [[Nokia]], and [[LG Corp|LG]].<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20080627212505/http://app.quotemedia.com/quotetools/newsStory.go?storyId=11549290&topic=TYPT&symbology=null&cp=null Apple Inc. and 9 Others Added to Greatly Expanded Dell, Inc. Patent Infringement Suit Brought by Typhoon Touch Technologies, Inc.], Business Wire, QuoteMedia.com, 2008-6-23.</ref><ref>Thompson Financial News, [http://www.forbes.com/feeds/afx/2008/06/24/afx5145899.html Apple, Nokia, others added to Typhoon Touch lawsuit launched vs Dell], Forbes, 2008-06-24.</ref> In 2010, Apple settled with Typhoon for an undisclosed amount and was then dismissed from the litigation as of September 2010.<ref>Marks, Joseph, [http://www.law360.com/articles/193783/apple-strikes-deal-in-typhoon-touch-screen-ip-spat Apple Strikes Deal In Typhoon Touch-Screen IP Spat], Law360, New York, 2011-9-15.</ref> Ultimately, Typhoon could not prevail against patent defense arguments of [[prior art]] and [[obviousness]], and earned itself infamy as a [[patent troll]].<ref name="Shrestha">Shrestha, Sannu, [http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/110/1/Shrestha.pdf Trolls Or Market-Makers? Samsung counter-sued Apple on April 22, 2011, filing federal complaints in courts in [[Seoul]], [[Tokyo]] and [[Mannheim]], Germany, alleging Apple infringed Samsung's patents related to mobile-communications technologies.<ref name="YangJun">Yang, Jun, [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-04-22/samsung-sues-apple-on-patent-infringement-claims-as-legal-dispute-deepens.html Samsung Counter Sues Apple as Patent Dispute Deepens], Bloomberg News, 2011-04-22.</ref> A German court (the Landgericht [[DÃ¼sseldorf]]) in August 2011 granted Apple's request for an EU-wide preliminary injunction barring Samsung from selling its Galaxy Tab v10.1 device on the grounds Samsung's product infringed on two of Apple's interface patents. After Samsung's allegations of evidence tampering were heard, the court rescinded the EU-wide injunction and granted Apple a lesser injunction that only applied to the German market.<ref>Foresman Chris, [http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2011/08/samsung-facing-eu-wide-injunction-against-galaxy-tab-101.ars Apple stops Samsung, wins EU-wide injunction against Galaxy Tab 10.1], ArsTechnica, 2011-08-09.</ref><ref>Jin, Hyunjoo and Gupta, Poornima, [http://ca.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idCATRE77928620110810?sp=true Apple blocks Samsung's Galaxy tablet in EU], Reuters Canada, 2011-08-10.</ref> In the same time period and in similar cases of related legal strategy, Apple filed contemporaneous suits against [[Motorola]] with regard to the [[Motorola Xoom|Xoom]] and against a German consumer electronics reseller named JAY-tech in the same German court, both for design infringement claims. Apple did not state the specific relief it sought in its complaints except for the preliminary injunctions, and is expected to amend its filings after the injunctions are granted.<ref>Foresman Chris, [http://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2011/08/apple-also-targeting-motorola-xoom-design-in-german-court.ars After Samsung win, Apple targets Motorola Xoom in German court], ArsTechnica, 2011-08-10.</ref>
Shortly after the release of the [[iPhone 4S]], Samsung filed motions for injunctions in courts in Paris and Milan to block further Apple iPhone sales in France and Italy, claiming the iPhone infringed on two separate patents of the [[W-CDMA (UMTS)|Wideband Code Division Multiple Access]] standard.<ref>Albanesius, Chloe, [http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2394136,00.asp Samsung Wants Apple's iPhone 4S Banned in France, Italy], PC Magazine, 2011-10-5.</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Samsung wants iPhone 4S banned in France and Italy|date=5 October 2011|work=BBC News|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-15184461|accessdate=5 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Samsung to Seek Block on iPhone in Europe|date=5 October 2011|first=Choe|last=Sang-Hun|work=New York Times|location=Seoul|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/06/technology/samsung-to-seek-block-on-iphone-in-europe.htm|accessdate=5 October 2011}}</ref> Samsung reportedly singled out the French and Italian markets as key electronic communications markets in Europe, and by filing suit in a different court, avoided going back to the German court where it had lost a round earlier in its battle with Apple.<ref>{{cite news|title=Samsung to Seek Ban on Apple iPhone 4S in France, Italy|date=5 October 2011|first=Evan| last=Ramstad|work=Wall Street Journal|location=Seoul|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203476804576612263249472784.html| accessdate=5 October 2011}}</ref> In late October 2011, the civil court in [[The Hague]] rejected Samsung's infringement arguments and denied Samsung's motion made there; a short time later an Australian federal court granted Apple's request for an injunction against Samsung's Galaxy Tab 10.1.<ref>[http://www.law.com/jsp/lawtechnologynews/PubArticleLTN.jsp?id=1202518995951 Dutch Court Refuses Samsung's Request to Ban iPhone, iPad Sales], Associated Press report on Law.com, 2011-10-17.</ref><ref>Miller, Amy, [http://www.law.com/jsp/lawtechnologynews/PubArticleLTN.jsp?id=1202518987573 Judge Stumps Samsung's Lawyers in Apple Patent Case], Law.com, 2011-10-17.</ref> Samsung agreed to an expedited appeal of the Australian decision in the hope that if it won its appeal before Christmas, it might salvage holiday sales that it would otherwise lose.<ref name="ssOzAppeal" />
===Licensing=== ====Apple Inc. v. Psystar Corporation==== On July 3, 2008, Apple Inc. filed a lawsuit against [[Psystar Corporation]]<ref name="appleVsPystar">{{cite web| url = http://stadium.weblogsinc.com/engadget/videos/Apple-Psystar-complaint.pdf| title = Apple Inc. v. Psystar Corporation| date = July 3, 2008| accessdate = 2008-08-10| page = 1| format = PDF}}</ref> alleging the computer company sold [[Intel]]-based systems with [[Mac OS X]] pre-installed. This act violated [[trademark]], [[copyright]], and [[software licensing]] laws, which is not in accordance with Apple's [[shrink wrap license]]. The [[shrink wrap]] [[license]] requires that Mac OS X only be installed on Apple-brand computers.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/idg/IDG_002570F3005978D8002574870067E25A.html?ref=technology | title=Apple Sues Mac Clone Maker Psystar | author=Keizer, Gregg | publisher=Computerworld | date=2008-07-15 | accessdate=2008-07-16}}</ref>
